folder: Between East and Broome Streets - Grand Street Ferry Terminal., Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)

A general view southward along East Street from Broome Street, as seen from the East River (Williamsburg) Bridge and showing the Corlears Hook section of Manhattan. Note the Grand Street Ferry in the immediate foreground. Observable on the right is the Manhattan Bridge.

January 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)

The same.

About 1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3)

A similar view. The bridge like structure seen across the river is a portion of the drydock in the U.S. Navy Yard.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: General view - [Manhattan - Between East and Broome Streets - Grand Street Ferry Terminal.]

folder: Manhattan Bridge, New York, N.Y.
text:
(1) Manhattan Bridge, is the second of the East River Bridges; following the Brooklyn Bridge further north. It begins at Canal Street, and Third Ave., and crosses over to Flatbush and Myrtle Aves., in Brooklyn. View taken from 54-58 Canal Street.

May 9, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same view, from a slightly different angle.

May 9, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) Same, taken from the Municipal Building at a later date.

June 12, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Cherry Street & James Slip, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Cherry Street, east from and including James Slip, to the Manhattan Bridge, west of Pike Slip. Also shown are Nos. 2-4 James Slip, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Cherry Street. Note the Salvation Army Settlement and Day Nursery on the left.
June 21, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same; at a later date. Shown on the north side of Cherry Street, is the completion of Knickerbocker Village. Also shown on the same side, is a clearance (Nos. 82-90 inclusive), adjoining the Salvation Army Building.
October 14, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Cherry Street - James Slip

folder: Prospect Street & Hudson Avenue, Brooklyn, NY
Cherry Street & Porter Avenue, Manhattan, NY
text:
Shrine atop the roof of the R.C. Retreat at No. 173 Cherry Street, ("Madonna House"), a haven of charity for the unfortunate of the lower east side, for years. During the last depression thousands were fed in its bread line.

March 6, 1934.

P. L. Sperr,

folder: South Street & James Slip, Manhattan, NY
text:
South street (foreground, buildings there upon), north side, east from James Slip (left, not seen in Nos. 1 and 2) to Pike Slip (under the Manhattan Bridge). The prominent structure seen is the plant of the New York Journal and American news paper. To the north of same will rise a large slum clearance project structure known as Knickerbocker Village. This appears in No. 3 in an almost completed form and will shortly be ready for occupancy.

January 8, 1934.
Views 1 and 2
July 31, 1934.

P. L. Sperr,
title: Manhattan: South Street - James Slip

folder: Water Street & Rutgers Slip, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Water Street, west from (No. 494) but not including Rutgers Slip, showing a lumber yard and scrap iron dump on the north side of the street (right) occupying the area from No. 504 (not shown) to 486 (6-story building). Also shown is a portion of the Manhattan Bridge.
March 22, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A more limited view of No. 1, extending only to Pike Slip, but showing the lumber yard in its entirety.
March 22, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
A detail of view No. 2, showing the area from No. 496 to 500, the scrap-iron dump.
March 22, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
(1)
Water Street, west from (No. 494) but not including Rutgers Slip, showing a lumber yard and scrap iron dump on the north side of the street (right) occupying the area from No. 504 (not shown) to 486 (6-story building). Also shown is a portion of the Manhattan Bridge.
March 22, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A more limited view of No. 1, extending only to Pike Slip, but showing the lumber yard in its entirety.
March 22, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
A detail of view No. 2, showing the area from No. 496 to 500, the scrap-iron dump.
March 22, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Water Street - Rutgers Slip

folder: Manhattan Bridge, New York, N.Y.
text:
Manhattan Bridge, across the East River showing in the background the Empire State Building silhouetted against the sky.

April 4, 1938.

P. L. Sperr
title: Bridges - Manhattan Bridge - [Brooklyn side.]

folder: Front Street & Gouverneur Slip, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Front Street, northside between the Slip and Jackson Streets, showing Manhattan, Bridge head.
September 18, 1939.

(2) and (3)
Front Street, west side of Jackson, north from South Street, showing across clearing on Front Street, rear of building facing on south side of Water Street.

P.L.Speer.
August 14, 1939.

Manhattan Bridge, New York, N.Y.
text:
The Manhattan Bridge and its Brooklyn shore as photographed from South Street in Manhattan.

1939

Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.
title: Bridges - Manhattan Bridge - [Brooklyn shore.]

folder: Manhattan Bridge, New York, N.Y.
text:
Manhattan Bridge, above the East River.
n.d.
Paul Thompson, photographers
title: Bridges - Manhattan Bridge - [East River.]

folder: Manhattan Bridge, New York, N.Y.
text:
One of Uncle Sam's Steel Warriors Departs for Winter Maneuvers
The U.S.S. Arkansas swings down the East River under the Manhattan Bridge on its way to the Carribean Sea to participate in the annual winter Maneuvers.
1930 International News Photo
title: Bridges - Manhattan Bridge - [East River.]
